I remember watching Falcon Heavy go and realizing just how many people were on that live stream. And then checking it on FB and seeing a staggering number there... and every new channel, etc. The world hasn't seen that kind of excitement since the Shuttle first flew, or the Moon landing. And if you ask me, getting the public that excited about space is more important than any of the missions, because it ensures that we will keep having missions. Cynics are absolutely right, it was a PR stunt... but it was a PR stunt that the world desperately needed. After Heavy, I would go on YT or FB streams of other launches, Parker Solar Probe for instance, and they were always far more popular than they had been in 2017 with people from all over curious about what it was, where it was going, how it would work, when is it launching, what is the white vapor coming out of it... what does that mean that they just said. Falcon Heavy changed everything. It gave the world a mascot. People started complimenting my FH shirt after the launch. I don't care what anyone says, your #1 pick is spot on, and for the right reason. Inspiring dreamers and doers is that important.

Tim, is it OK if I comment to you on details of your script? Fellow commenters, this is for Tim so you needn't read it. Tim, my degree is in broadcast journalism. I did TV news for a little while and I am familiar with efficient and descriptive speaking. I'm no one special and many statements below can be taken as my opinion. Still, you may want to consider my observations from this awards segment:

I found your speaking style Inspiring - full of energy/enthusiasm. Your thorough research and captivating B-roll kept me glued to the screen. The insight you into social/political/economic/scientific ramifications of the listed space achievements makes your scope of commentary exceptional . I would like to point out some specific instances in which you could be more concise or express yourself in a more interesting manner:

At 14:40 you say "very precisely." Precise means Very, as in very accurate, so that is redundant. Using fewer words will get your point across better and make you even more enjoyable to listen to.
23:40 has a small redundancy: "They Completely re-did the Entire flight computer system." Either "completely" or "entire" would do it. "Computer" and "system" may also be redundant. EG: "They redesigned the entire flight computer." (If that doesn't seem to pack the emphasis you desire, I understand. Personal style is important too, and I think you've got a fun style.)
23:58 "..before they have the same issue Potentially crop up on another flight." "Before" and "potentially" both reference before/after. It's either "before they have the same issue on another flight" or "because of the potential of the same issue on another flight. For this statement, I think "before they have the same..." would be best.
33:00 ..."at this Point in Time." You have a choice of "at this point" (since the context is time anyway) or "at this time" because "this" indicated something specific - a point.

At 15:50 you use "incredible" for the first of at least six instances. It's a popular word because of its power but when it's overused it loses its punch. "Unbelievable" or "unimaginable" could be used sometimes. More "incredibles:" 18:00, 18:15 "incredibly common" (maybe "surprisingly" instead) 21:10 "incredibly advanced"....maybe explain why it is incredible/unbelievable/surprising. Because if it is not actually any of those, then use another adjective. 22:50 "incredibly advanced technology," instead, maybe something like "technical quantum leap" or "game-changing innovation" and then an example, such as the carbon fiber structure you mentioned.
22:25 "incredible year" could be "triumphant year." 27:00 "incredibly engenius" could be "amazingly engenius" or "shows mind-blowing creativity" and follow with your example.

Another popular word is "massive." It loses power when overused or put in the wrong context. Example: 21:55 "massively inspirational." How much physical inertia does inspiration have? :-) Perhaps "extremely inspirational," or "it's heart-lifting to witness..." (Maybe that's not so great either but I'm sure you get my point.)
24:00 "...massive rocket factory..." Try "expansive" ...it avoids the overuse and speaks "volumes" about the ambitious nature of the facility. (BTW I loved "..evil lair." :-)

And now for....wait for it....."Awesome."
26:40 "Really Awesome." Really? Please excuse my whimsical sarcasm: What makes them "Really" Awesome? Is that different from "Very Awesome?" What's "Awesome?" It is related to "awe-inspiring." When one's mouth hangs open in wonder the sound "awe" may even come out. (Witness Laura Dern's character in "Jurassic Park" when she sees the 80-foot brontosaurus for the first time.) The word has also come to mean "OK, that's good." Like "I brought my watch for repair." "Awesome, we can fix it."
So "awesome" either means something truly spectacular or something perfectly mundane. It's weird. In your case, you mean "spectacular" or "wondrous," and you could use those two words sometimes instead of the "a" word. :-) Actually, just about anything can be substituted because "awesome" is being used for everything.
30:00 "...awesome landing failure." Actually, that was awe-inspiring! 33:50 "..awesome science experiments." Why were they "a?" Maybe they are "imaginative," "promising," "innovative."
You advertise "Lots of Awesome merch." Could it instead be "unique," "historically important," "perfect conversation piece?"

A few power words just came to mind:
"The sight of the Tesla soaring above the Earth was captivating. " (Maybe it was even stunning.)
"India's success has been stunning." (Your merch may include "thought-provoking," "colorful" or "eye-catching" pictures, but they probably aren't stunning. Viewing them probably won't make people feel like they've been hit by a baseball bat or had a glorious spontaneous sexual experience. Of course, I haven't seen your merch, so maybe I'm wrong :-)
If Rocket Lab is using more carbon fiber than anyone has before, then, "RL's thorough use of carbon fiber in the fuselage is unprecedented." (But probably not stunningly unprecedented.)

Things I like: Well, practically everything. OH! And I just noticed you said "stunning" for RL's new facility. Yeah, it probably is close to being stunning.
Your enlightening thoughts about the usefulness of communications cubesats on Mars missions. 24:45 Nice phrase: "Mind-boggling launch schedule." 35:00 "..flood of exciting data."
36:00 "..exponentially bigger rockets" and "major paradigm shift" "Major" may be redundant with "paradigm", but it does emphasize the point well. I love the social media graphs.
37ish "The public has "awakened" to spaceflight again."
39:40 "Quite literally" actually used appropriately! The "L-Word" is so overused in our culture people use it to express its opposite, "figuratively," but you don't. Thank you! :-)
Your Falcon Heavy segment was a convincing thesis. I was around for Apollo and I think you're right, SpaceX is inspiring the public.

The more I thought about why they used the Roadster the more I think it was a smart idea.

1. It's an electric car. That means one big battery. Which means power for communication and for sensors.

2. Perfect for putting a dummy in a space suit you want to experiment on.

3. Package details are known. For example weight distribution, mount points etc.

4. Second hand so that makes it really cheap.

5. Best PR stunt ever.

Outstanding my friend. I was watching various 2-5 minute videos at Starbucks when I came across this one. No idea of the length. Nevertheless, I could not stop watching. Then towards the end to watch your tribute to Space X Falcon Heavy and relating to the kind of excitement and global enthusiasm the original Apollo missions enjoyed... brought tears. Sounds silly, I know, but let me tell you why. I am child of the 60’s and can remember Apollo 11. My name is Michael and my brother is Neal, so by namesake alone we felt we were astronauts. We were in Okinawa, but there wasn’t anyone I knew that didn’t know about the mission. Then in second grade the school gathered all students into the gym to have a moment of silence for Apollo 13. Imagine that many students quiet. I remember the shuttle missions and know where I was for the tragic ones. However, my interest in space exploration began to wane for some time until the Mars missions. In particular Curiosity... Seven minutes of terror and all... but when I watched the Falcon Heavy and the Tesla in space... not only was I excited but so many that I spoke with had something to say... so... cheers, thumbs up, and thank you for a delightful and inspiring production. I know you worked hard and it is obviously a labor of love.

You forgot another important thing about Falcon Heavy, it is the first privately funded SHLV in history, sure most of the time it will be operated as a HLV roughly equivalent to the 551 Atlas V with landing all 3 boosters, but even expending just the center core you get pretty close to the 50t to LEO mark used to define SHLVs, making it not only the most powerful operational rocket, but one of the most powerful and capable rockets to achieve orbit. It is more capable of doing high energy deep space missions than D4H, and there is even a proposal to add a Star 48 kick stage to it, for Europa Clipper, remember, the Falcon second stage actually packs more ∆v than the current Centaurs, despite being Kerolox.

Anyway, throwing away a Falcon 9 uppers stage and having 1 booster land is actually better than throwing away the same kind of upper stage but having 2 MORE boosters flying and coming back. It is ONLY when more performance is required to come back and land with a particular payload and mission, AND Falcon Heavy closes the gap, that Falcon Heavy becomes a reuse-benefit over Falcon 9...the 65% vs 95% numbers are rather misleading in themselves IMO because it is literally just adding boosters to get the higher percentage, thats not improvement as it is presented.

I remember being at home ready to go to school in February and watching Sunrise. (Australia news) and seeing them say “A new rocket that has the most payload capability in operation is about to launch!”, I knew I should wait a few mins to watch that launch. I excepted it to be around 5 mins then I would go to school, but 5 mins turned to 10, then to 20 as I researched what it was and what SpaceX was. When I did eventually get to school I couldn’t get my mind off of it. I was obsessed. Ever since I downloaded Kerbal Space Program and started to watch real launches I fell in love with it all. It was amazing and will forever remember the moment I got home and downloaded game and researched what every little part did, with the help of your videos. I was hooked and  more 10 months later I still am. This pulled me out of a rough time for me and I thank you SpaceX and you Tim for getting me a great new hobby and a new thing to strive for on this little blue, wet rock. ✌️♥️
